content.full_text:
Abraham Lincoln to John M. McCalla, 7 December 18481 Your early attention is respectfully solicited to the enclosed papers, as I am desirous
               of advising my constituents of the settlement of the claims at an early day.2
paragraphs: Abraham Lincoln to John M. McCalla, 7 December 18481

Your early attention is respectfully solicited to the enclosed papers, as I am desirous
               of advising my constituents of the settlement of the claims at an early day.2
citations: Roy P. Basler, ed.,The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln(Westport, CT: Greenwood, 1974),  10:12;Illinois Public Domain Land Tract Sales, Jo Daviess County, 711:83, 85, 86, Illinois State Archives, Springfield, IL.

footnotes.text:
1The writer of the body of this letter is unknown.  Abraham Lincoln only signed his
                  name.

2The enclosed papers Lincoln references were not with this letter, and they have not
                  been found.  The docketing on the back of the letter suggests that the papers concerned
                  James Milton, deceased, and Thomas Leakley, Company F, 2nd Illinois Volunteers, whose
                  back pay from their service in theMexican Warwas being sought by William Milton, James Milton’s  father, through Lincoln and the
                  firm of Hempstead & Washburne.  In aletterdated March 22, 1849,Elihu B. Washburnesuggested that Lincoln might have received a land warrant for William Milton due
                  for his son’s service.  Public land sales records show that Milton received 240 acres
                  by warrant in February and April 1848 in Apple River Township in northernJo Daviess County.Roy P. Basler, ed.,The Collected Works of Abraham Lincoln(Westport, CT: Greenwood, 1974),  10:12;Illinois Public Domain Land Tract Sales, Jo Daviess County, 711:83, 85, 86, Illinois State Archives, Springfield, IL.
3“Seekly” or “Seekley” is most likely an incorrect spelling for Thomas Leakley (Leekley).
4The abbrevation “A. G.” could stand for “Attorney General” or “Adjutant General.”
